item.title: Unity ML-Agents Toolkit v0.4 and Udacity Deep Reinforcement Learning Nanodegree - Unity Blog
item.description:
Unity ML-Agents Toolkit v0.4 and Udacity Deep Reinforcement Learning Nanodegree - Unity Blog

We are happy to announce the release of the latest version of ML-Agents: v0.4. It contains a number of features, which we hope everyone will enjoy. It includes the option to train your environments directly from the editor, rather than as built executables, making iteration time much quicker.

item.title: MURA Dataset: Towards Radiologist-Level Abnormality Detection in Musculoskeletal Radiographs
item.description:
MURA Dataset: Towards Radiologist-Level Abnormality Detection in Musculoskeletal Radiographs

MURA is a large dataset of bone X-rays. Algorithms are tasked with determining whether an X-ray study is normal or abnormal.

item.title: Speech Processing for Machine Learning: Filter banks, Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) and What's In-Between
item.description:
Speech Processing for Machine Learning: Filter banks, Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) and What's In-Between

Understanding and computing filter banks and MFCCs and a discussion on why are filter banks becoming increasingly popular.

item.title: Tutorial on implementing YOLO v3 from scratch in PyTorch
item.description:
Tutorial on implementing YOLO v3 from scratch in PyTorch

Object detection is a domain that has benefited immensely from the recent developments in deep learning. Recent years have seen people develop many algorithms for object detection, some of which include YOLO, SSD, Mask RCNN and RetinaNet. For the past few months, I've been working on improving object detection at a research lab.

item.title: Secure Computations as Dataflow Programs - Cryptography and Machine Learning
item.description:
Secure Computations as Dataflow Programs - Cryptography and Machine Learning

Mixing both for private data analysis

item.title: Lessons from My First Two Years of AI Research
item.description:
Lessons from My First Two Years of AI Research

Tom Silver | About Me | Favorite Papers | Blog By Tom Silver A friend of mine who is about to start a career in artificial intelligence research recently asked what I wish I had known when I started two years ago. Below are some lessons I have learned so far.

item.title: Lessons Learned Reproducing a Deep Reinforcement Learning Paper
item.description:
Lessons Learned Reproducing a Deep Reinforcement Learning Paper

There are a lot of neat things going on in deep reinforcement learning. One of the coolest things from last year was OpenAI and DeepMind's work on training an agent using feedback from a human rather than a classical reward signal.

item.title: Monte Carlo Tree Search - beginners guide - Machine learning blog
item.description:
Monte Carlo Tree Search - beginners guide - Machine learning blog

For quite a long time, a common opinion in academic world was that machine achieving human master performance level in the game of Go was far from realistic. It was considered a 'holy grail' of AI - a milestone we were quite far away from reaching within upcoming decade.

item.title: Facebook AI | Tools | Open Source Deep Learning Tools
item.description:
Facebook AI | Tools | Open Source Deep Learning Tools

Experience flexible research and accelerated production with Facebook's ecosystem of open source, state-of-the-art AI developer tools.

item.title: Grokking Deep Reinforcement Learning
item.description:
Grokking Deep Reinforcement Learning

The must-have book, for anyone that wants to have a profound understanding of deep reinforcement learning.
